Authors:
Tsutomu Hattori, Yuko Ota, Kozue Sotome, Tsutomu
Hattori
Title:
Two new species of Fulvifomes (Basidiomycota,
Hymenochaetaceae) on threatened tree species in Japan
Keywords:
Host specificity, Hymenochaetales, Phellinus, Polypore,
Red-list
Abstract:
We describe two new species of Fulvifomes from Japan based
on morphological observations and phylogenetic investigations on the LSU
and ITS sequences. These two species were both determined as Phellinus
rimosus by former mycologists, but both are morphologically distinct
from the authentic specimen of P. rimosus. Comparison with other
Fulvifomes spp. and some authentic specimens, we conclude that these two
species are undescribed. Fulvifomes boninensis sp. nov. is characterized
by the perennial basidiomata, sulcate pileus surface becoming rimose,
lack of a distinct crust on the pileus surface, pores 46/mm, subdimitic
hyphal system in the context, and ellipsoid basidiospores measuring 56.5
× 3.55 µm. This species is endemic to the Bonin Islands, Japan, and is
specific to Morus boninensis, a red-listed tree species. Fulvifomes
imazekii sp. nov. is characterized by the perennial basidiomata, sulcate
and velutinous to shortly tomentose pileus surface, lack of a crust on
the pileus surface, pores 67/mm, dimitic hyphal system in the context,
and broadly ellipsoid basidiospores measuring 4.56 × 3.55 µm. This
species is specific to Berchemiella berchemiaefolia, and known only from
Mt. Yokogura-yama, in Kochi prefecture, Japan. Fulvifomes boninensis and
F. imazekii are considered threatened, because of the high specificity
to a threatened tree and the limited distribution for the former and the
extremely small number of “mature individuals” for the latter.
